White House Economic Advisor Hassett said negotiations with China would not still be ongoing if progress was not made, while also commented that he expects strong US growth in Q2 and the rest of 2019. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May reportedly told the 1922 committee members that she will hand over leadership once Brexit is delivered according to Huffington Post. Furthermore, other reports suggested that she will not stay for the next stage of negotiations and others noted that will step down in the summer. (Huffington Post/Daily Mirror/The Guardian/Twitter)

DUP said it will not support the government on the Brexit deal if it tables a 3rd meaningful vote and that the party cannot agree to anything which threatens the union, while DUP's Dodds also said we will vote against PM May's deal and will not abstain when it comes to the union. (Newswires)

UK ERG source suggested 40 lawmakers have switched to back PM May's deal and 40 are undecided, according to The Times' Sam Coates. Separately, ERG head Jacob Rees-Mogg earlier said he will back PM May’s deal if the DUP abstain and Brexiteer Boris Johnson is also reportedly to back PM May's deal which was in line with hints he made yesterday. (Newswires/Twitter)

Brexit Minister Barclay said that they will table a motion for the Parliament to sit on Friday, while Downing Street sources also suggested a Meaningful Vote 3 is 'pencilled in' for Friday, according to ITV's Brand. (Newswires/ITV)

ECB's Villeroy (Dovish) said the Eurozone is facing a slowdown, not a recession and is hoping to see a pick-up through the year. (Newswires)

ECB staff are reportedly working on models for a tiered deposit rate and working on options to return some but not all of the cash it collects from a charge on excess liquidity, according to sources. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) found some relief today, supported by positive mentions at Piper Jaffray as well as being exonerated from one of its Qualcomm (QCOM) lawsuits; Qualcomm (QCOM) also faced headwinds from a Neutral initiation at JPM, citing downside risk from Apple litigation. Centene (CNC) nosedived on the announcement it would be acquiring WellCare Health (WCG), which consequentially surged; competitor CVS Health (CVS) dipped lower. Lennar (LEN) missed on top and bottom line estimates, but gave constructive guidance, leading it open higher; competitors PulteGroup (PHM) and D.R. Horton (DHI) also outperformed. Paychex (PAYX) drifted lower on a mixed outlook, despite beating earnings estimates. Ralph Lauren (RL) and Papa John’s (PZZA) both benefitted from upgrades at Wells Fargo and Stifel respectively. Apple supplier Lumentum (LITE) traded higher after an upgrade at Morgan Stanley. DowDuPont (DWDP) sold off on news that it was to be replaced by Dow Inc. (DOW), it’s spin-off, in the DJIA. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) erased losses after a New Jersey jury cleared it of claims of its talcum powder causing cancer. A dampening of risk sentiment saw high beta stocks push lower, particularly chipmakers such as Western Digital (WDC), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Texan Instruments (TXN). SPX -0.46% at 2805, NDX -0.58% at 7308, DJI -0.13% at 25626.

Most of the early action overnight/Europe trade was focussed on the short-end, underpinned by comments from Fed governor nominee Moore, who called on the Fed to immediately cut rates by 50bps. This saw the curve bull steepen. There was focus on a German 10yr auction, which sold at negative yields for the first time since 2016.The long-end of the yield curve continued to test new lows (lowest in over a year), with participants continuing to note that the 30-year bucket is the only part of the curve with its head above the effective fed funds rate. On that note, the 3m/10y inversion deepened to over 10bps on Wednesday trade; the market has been rationalising these moves with more circumspection, though concerns about the growth outlook are clearly evident. Next week’s survey data and jobs data may provide the next major catalyst for the narrative to be tweaked. Meanwhile, the belly of the curve saw decent action; in early trade a block sale of the FVM9 in 5k was followed by a large sale (15k); later in the session, some desks had reported real money was profit taking in the belly. US T-note futures (M9) settled 9 ticks higher at 124-22.

UK Parliament results on indicative votes shows no majority was reached on any Brexit options
content:
· (B) No Deal; Tabled by John Baron [Con] - The legal default if negotiations do not achieve agreement on a deal, proposes leaving the EU without a deal on 12th April. No technical issue for the EU.  (160 For vs. 400 Against)

 

· (D) Common Market 2.0; Tabled by Nick Boles [Con] - Regarded as the leading ‘soft’ Brexit plan; with UK membership of the European Free Trade Association & European Economic Area. Note – this would therefore commit the UK to the free movement of people. There has been caution from both EFTA & EU about upsetting EEA, but general model might be viable. Paragraph 2, however, making this binding likely will not work due to this being a negotiation. Note: Labour party are encouraging support for this amendment, but it is not being whipped as it is not technically party policy - though implication is on Corbyn to support this.  (188 For vs. 283 Against)

 

· (H) EEA/EFTA; Tabled by George Eustace [Con] - Should seek to remain in the EEA and rejoin the EFTA, whilst remaining outside of a customs union with the UK. Similar to D, except that UK can stay in EEA, so likely to see some dispute from the EU.  (65 For vs. 377 Against)

 

· (J) Customs Union; Tabled by Ken Clarke [Con] - Compels the gov’t to negotiate for a permanent and comprehensive UK-wide customs union with the EU. Seen as a softer Brexit, although PM May is against this scenario as it defies the 2017 Tory manifesto. Compatible with EU options. Note: Labour will whip to support this amendment.  (234 For vs. 272 Against)

 

· (K) Labour; Tabled by Jeremy Corbyn [Lab] - Motion proposes their plan for a close economic relationship with the EU, which features a comprehensive customs union and a close alignment with the single market. Labour's alternative plan" includes customs union (OK), 'close alignment' with single market (UK's choice) with 'shared institutions' (unlikely if not fully inside single market) and participation in various EU programmes (probably OK). Note: Labour will whip to support this amendment.  (237 For vs. 307 Against)

 

· (L) Revoke Article 50; Tabled by Joanna Cherry [SNP] - If the Gov’t has not passed a deal it would be required to stage a no-deal vote before 12th April scheduled departure, then in the scenario that MP’s do not authorise a no-deal PM May would be required to revoke Article 50. Fully within UK power as long as revocation is unconditional  (184 For vs. 293 Against)

 

· (M) Second ‘Confirmatory’ referendum; Tabled by Margaret Beckett [Lab] - Some Remainers have argued that the public now has a better understanding of Brexit and therefore should be asked again. Requires a long extension, which EU is likely to grant on these grounds. Note: Labour will whip to support this amendment.  (268 For vs. 295 Against)

 

· (O) Contingent Preferential Arrangements; Tabled by Marcus Fysh [Con] - Gov’t to attempt agree upon preferential trade agreements with the EU, in the scenario that a WA in not implemented. Not compatible with EU arrangements as some parts of “O” don’t exist in practice.  (139 For vs. 422 Against)

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 27 March 2019: May conditionally offers to quit if MV3 passes
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP 27 March 2019: May conditionally offers to quit if MV3 passes

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar up, treasuries up, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: Trade balance narrows; ECB to remodel its deposit rate in a tiered system; PM May offers to step down provided her deal passes; crude stocks show a surprise build

* AHEAD: New Zealand Business Outlook & Own Activity, German State & National CPI (Preliminary), US GDP (Final) & Initial Jobless Claims, Japanese Tokyo CPI & Retail Sales, Japanese Industrial Output & Unemployment Rate, Fed's Quarles, Clarida, Bostic, Williams & Bullard, ECB's de Guindos, Nowotny, Knot & Villeroy, RBNZ's Orr, Supply from the US & Italy

 

* US TRADE BALANCE: Many were encouraged by a narrowing of the trade deficit in January by more than was expected; indeed, GDP trackers were nudged higher after the data. However, the data was driven by a larger than expected fall in imports, which doesn't augur too well. "Nonetheless, with imports likely to have been flat or fallen slightly in the first quarter, net trade is on track to be a positive for first quarter GDP growth," Capital Economics said, and the consultancy now expects growth to come in around 2.0% annualised, up from our previous estimate of 1.5%. Other trackers were more moderate; Atlanta Fed's GDPnow model was tracking 1.5% vs 1.3% previously.

* ECB: ECB staff are reportedly working on models for a tiered deposit rate, according to sources, and staff are working on options to return some -- but not all -- of the cash it collects from a charge on excess liquidity, the sources said. The report followed comments from the ECB's Draghi earlier in the session, where he said that accommodative monpol has supported bank profitability in recent years, and the central bank's conventional and unconventional measures have improved the quality of credit. Draghi made the case that the ECB's measures have also increased demand for loans, and more than offset the negative impact of compressed margins. Draghi also said that the central bank is now seeing a more persistent deterioration of external demand, and that current data suggests that there are some signs that external demand may be effecting investment via manufacturing value chains within the Euro Area. The central bank chief also said that the domestic economy has remained relatively resilient, repeated that risks to the outlook remain tilted to the downside, and repeated that the ECB remains confident that the sustained convergence of inflation to our aim has been delayed rather than derailed. Also at the ECB watcher's conference, outgoing chief economist Praet said that in any case, the central bank stands ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure sustained inflation convergence towards levels below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. Praet said all our instruments remain available following the return to rate forward guidance as our main policy tool, and TLTROs are flexible tools with parameters that could be recalibrated. ECB's VP de Guindos stated that the Euro area is not immune to spill-overs from other regions, in particular to shocks emanating from the US, adding that low economic growth raises concerns about sovereign debt sustainability. Meanwhile, ECB's Mersch said the ECB continue to assess the impact of their measures, and of negative interest rates in particular, on areas such as bank profitability, and to consider whether ECB mix of policy measures remains suitable and proportionate.

* BREXIT: UK PM May reportedly told 1922 Committee of backbench Tory MPs that she would step down as PM once Brexit is delivered. The suggestion, sources said, was that another leader would be take over negotiations on trade with the EU, as a result; this would imply that May steps down before 22 May (with a new leader in place by mid-July). However, her pledge seems to have been caveated on her deal passing, and ahead of indicative votes on various Brexit options (results to be announced after 2000 GMT on Wednesday), the government has been manoeuvring to place MV3 on the docket for Friday. At this stage, it is unclear whether May has garnered enough support for her deal with this pledge, however, the initial indications are that at least some Brexiteers may have been persuaded by her gambit (Times reported that at least 40 Tory Brexiteers would back May, 40 were undecided). It is also unclear what May's plans would be in the event that her deal did not secure the requisite support.

* WTI (K9) SETTLED USD 0.53 LOWER AT USD 59.41; BRENT (K9) SETTLED USD 0.14 LOWER AT USD 67.83. Oil prices pared back Tuesday’s rally, in particular WTI, as the market rolled on the release of last night’s surprise build API release, which was confirmed by today’s official DOE data. The DOEs showed crude stocks building 2.8mln bbls, a reversal from the near 10mln bbl draw last week and a surprise from the expected 1.2mln bbl draw, but confirming the API’s reported 1.9mln build; Cushing also saw a c. 500k bbl build. On a side note, the products painted a more bullish picture with gasoline and distillates both drawing more than expected, perhaps limiting some of the down side risk. The US still continues to produce at a record high of 12.1mln BPD for the week. Elsewhere, it was reported that Russia’s production level was at 11.3mln BPD up to now for the month of March, only marginally lower than February’s 11.34 level and not at its quota of 11.19; Iraq also resumed its southern oil exports following a stoppage due to weather conditions, adding further pressure to the energy complex. Libya’s NOC said that it could produce up to 1.4mln BPD if the country found political stability.

* SPX -0.46% at 2805, NDX -0.58% at 7308, DJI -0.13% at 25626. SECTORS: Energy -0.70%, Materials -0.09%, Industrials +0.10%, Cons Discretionary -0.26%, Cons Staples -0.40%, Healthcare -0.81%, Financials -0.44%, Tech -0.55%, Telecoms -0.54%, Utilities -0.67%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) found some relief today, supported by positive mentions at Piper Jaffray as well as being exonerated from one of its Qualcomm (QCOM) lawsuits; Qualcomm (QCOM) also faced headwinds from a Neutral initiation at JPM, citing downside risk from Apple litigation. Centene (CNC) nosedived on the announcement it would be acquiring WellCare Health (WCG), which consequentially surged; competitor CVS Health (CVS) dipped lower. Lennar (LEN) missed on top and bottom line estimates, but gave constructive guidance, leading  it open higher; competitors PulteGroup (PHM) and D.R. Horton (DHI) also outperformed. Paychex (PAYX) drifted lower on a mixed outlook, despite beating earnings estimates. Ralph Lauren (RL) and Papa John’s (PZZA) both benefitted from upgrades at Wells Fargo and Stifel respectively. Apple supplier Lumentum (LITE) traded higher after an upgrade at Morgan Stanley. DowDuPont (DWDP) sold off on news that it was to be replaced by Dow Inc. (DOW), it’s spin-off, in the DJIA. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) erased losses after a New Jersey jury cleared it of claims of its talcum powder causing cancer. A dampening of risk sentiment saw high beta stocks push lower, particularly chipmakers such as Western Digital (WDC), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Texan Instruments (TXN).

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 9 TICKS HIGHER AT 124-22. Most of the early action overnight/Europe trade was focussed on the short-end, underpinned by comments from Fed governor nominee Moore, who called on the Fed to immediately cut rates by 50bps. This saw the curve bull steepen. There was focus on a German 10yr auction, which sold at negative yields for the first time since 2016.The long-end of the yield curve continued to test new lows (lowest in over a year), with participants continuing to note that the 30-year bucket is the only part of the curve with its head above the effective fed funds rate. On that note, the 3m/10y inversion deepened to over 10bps on Wednesday trade; the market has been rationalising these moves with more circumspection, though concerns about the growth outlook are clearly evident. Next week’s survey data and jobs data may provide the next major catalyst for the narrative to be tweaked. Meanwhile, the belly of the curve saw decent action; in early trade a block sale of the FVM9 in 5k was followed by a large sale (15k); later in the session, some desks had reported real money was profit taking in the belly.

* 7-YEAR PREVIEW: The last 7s auction was solid, stopping through the WI by 0.8bps, while cover was the highest since August (three of the last four have stopped through, now). Barclays notes that the investor and bidder takedowns for February were similar to January, “namely, domestic and foreign investor takedown was over 60% and 20% respectively.” The bank also notes that on-the-run 7s were trading cheap vs older 7s in repo vs other auction cycles, and this suggests that there is room for the auction to set-up. 

* FX WRAP: EUR marginally lower, USD marginally higher (yields generally lower, stocks down; hints of ECB easing also cited; weak China data didn't help). Analysts have observed that the trade-weighted buck remains firm, despite last week's Fed dovishness, with the prevailing wisdom that the grind higher is on the back of concerns about global growth, as well as the dovish pivot of other global central banks. On that note, the NZD was slammed after the RBNZ suggested its next rate move could be a rate cut; that also put some pressure on AUD, with expectations that we could see something similar from the RBA next week. GBP is clinging on to gains above 1.32 with a series of indicative votes on the slate for this evening, while May's MV3 (potentially Friday) is also seen garnering Brexiteer support. EMFX succumbed to USD strength, while commodity FX gained no support from the crude complex.

PREVIEW: US Treasury to sell USD 41BLN in 5-year notes
content:
* TREASURY SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction USD 131bln in 2yr (USD 40bln Tue), 5yr (USD 41bln, Wed), 7yr *USD 32bln, Thu), and an FRN (USD 18bln, Wed). USD 71.5bln matured at the month-end settlement, implying the Treasury will raise a net USD 59.5bln in new supply. USD 22.4bln of Fed holdings mature at the month-end settlement, and the Fed will add-on USD 7.9bln to 2yr, USD 8.1bln to 5yr, and USD 6.3bln to 7yr.     

* FOMC: Last week's FOMC meeting was more dovish than anticipated, with the Fed announcing that it will slow the balance sheet run-off in May, ending in September, and reducing caps on monthly redemptions to USD 15bln, from USD 30bln; it will also be reinvesting MBS coupons back into Treasuries. "With runoff ending in September, we think that Treasury will likely cut coupon auction sizes later this year (potentially focused in the 2-3y sector). Runoff ending in September will decrease Treasury issuance by about $100bn compared with runoff continuing throughout the year," TD Securities says. "The Fed will have to reinvest MBS paydowns in the open market starting in October. Starting in Q4 2020, we look for the Fed to purchase additional Treasuries in the open market to offset the growth in currency in circulation."      

* 5-YEAR PREVIEW: The February 5-year auction was digested well, as was the January auction, despite the richening of the curve in the run-up. "Auction performance in 2019 has been strong, with both auctions stopping through," Barclays noted, "previous to this, July 2018 was the last time the 5y auction stopped through." The bank also points out that final demand (that of direct and indirect participation) at 5-year auctions are near post-crisis highs with an allocation of 80% as primary dealer down has fallen. In terms of valuation, the bank observes that on-the-run 5-year notes are trading fair vs older 5s in spot and in forward

subject: Daily FX Wrap: dovish Central Bank impulses, divergent data and EM depreciation
content:
USD

The Dollar has rebounded from worst levels and the DXY is eyeing 97.000 again within a 96.978-680 range in wake of significantly better than expected US trade data that breaks the run or at least interrupts a sequence of disappointing releases. However, chartists are still looking for a close above 96.956 Fib resistance and the Greenback remains partly at the whim of G10 counterparts and broader risk sentiment.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi and Aussie have extended already heavy overnight loss vs their US peer to 0.6790 and 0.7075 respectively as waning risk appetite compounded the pressure induced by a more dovish than anticipated RBNZ (OCR now more likely to be lowered vs an even chance of a cut or hike previously) and weak Chinese industrial profits (worst performance in nearly a decade).

CAD

The other non-US Dollar has also deteriorated over the course of the session as Canada’s trade balance widened more than forecast in January and official DoE crude inventories rose in line with API stocks and also against consensus for a draw to the detriment of crude prices. Usd/Cad hit highs of circa 1.3430 in response vs 1.3375 or so at one stage.

NOK

Also a hefty loser on a mixture of risk-off trade and data disappointment as Norway’s Labour Force Survey revealed a surprise rise in January’s unemployment rate, with Eur/Nok up to 9.7300 from around 9.6250 at the low.

JPY

The major outlier and outperformer due to its greater appeal compared to the Buck in times of stress and safe-haven positioning, with Usd/Jpy drifting down towards 110.25 vs 110.70, while Yen crosses in general are back-pedalling from recent highs, ie Eur/Jpy retesting 124.00 and key technical support just below the big figure.

GBP 

The Pound has remained relatively stable through all the daily Brexit bluster, barring a brief period of selling that pulled Cable back down through 1.3200 to revisit Tuesday’s low as Eur/Gbp climbed to circa 0.8550. In short, the procedural vote to table amendments for IVs has now been passed and the Speaker has chosen 8 of the 16 for debate and voting later, while the DUP is expected to make an official statement after more talks with the Government about the Withdrawal Agreement. On that note, a 3rd MV could come as early as tomorrow, or more likely on Friday. Cable is now just above 1.3200 and Eur/Gbp a little over 0.8500 awaiting unfolding Parliament developments – see our headline for more detailed latest analysis.

EM

A blanket sea of red for regional currencies as the Real, and Lira slump around 2% or more vs the Usd in line with the overall risk averse tone and specific negative issues like Brazilian pension reform and a Turkish liquidity squeeze that saw swaps leap to over 1330% at one point. Usd/Brl and Usd/Try now just shy of 3.9500 and 5.4250, but up to 3.9600 and 5.4645 at their peaks.

UPDATED BREXIT SITUATION REPORT AND ANALYSIS
content:
*TODAY'S SCHEDULE (GMT)

  • 14:00 - House of Commons to debate different options
  • 15:00 - House Speaker to pick options to be voted on
  • 17:00 - PM May to address 1922 Committee
  • 19:00 - Debate of Brexit options to conclude
  • 19:30 - Voting to start on indicative votes
  • 20:30 - Indicative vote results to be published

N.B. 1 - High ranking Tory members expect PM May to use today's address to set a date for her resignations, according to Sun's Political Editor Dunn

*WHAT’S NEXT: In light of the Letwin amendment passing, today MPs will vote on a series of options to establish what could command a majority in parliament. The result of any such indicative votes would not be binding on the government as it goes against the Tory manifesto. There is no official list of options, although one has been generated by the Commons select committee for exiting the EU.

*INDICATIVE VOTE PROCESS: .

BALLOT VOTE: Today's indicative vote is said to include a ballot paper where all options are voted on at once (Yes/No vote). House Speaker will decide which options are on the ballot and the results will likely be declared at night.

*SELECTED OPTIONS FOR THE INDICATIVE VOTE

· (B) No Deal; Tabled by John Baron [Con] - The legal default if negotiations do not achieve agreement on a deal, proposes leaving the EU without a deal on 12th April. No technical issue for the EU.

· (D) Common Market 2.0; Tabled by Nick Boles [Con] - Regarded as the leading ‘soft’ Brexit plan; with UK membership of the European Free Trade Association & European Economic Area. Note – this would therefore commit the UK to the free movement of people. There has been caution from both EFTA & EU about upsetting EEA, but general model might be viable. Paragraph 2, however, making this binding likely will not work due to this being a negotiation. Note: Labour party are encouraging support for this amendment, but it is not being whipped as it is not technically party policy - though implication is on Corbyn to support this.

· (H) EEA/EFTA; Tabled by George Eustace [Con] - Should seek to remain in the EEA and rejoin the EFTA, whilst remaining outside of a customs union with the UK. Similar to D, except that UK can stay in EEA, so likely to see some dispute from the EU.

· (J) Customs Union; Tabled by Ken Clarke [Con] - Compels the gov’t to negotiate for a permanent and comprehensive UK-wide customs union with the EU. Seen as a softer Brexit, although PM May is against this scenario as it defies the 2017 Tory manifesto. Compatible with EU options. Note: Labour will whip to support this amendment.

· (K) Labour; Tabled by Jeremy Corbyn [Lab] - Motion proposes their plan for a close economic relationship with the EU, which features a comprehensive customs union and a close alignment with the single market. Labour's alternative plan" includes customs union (OK), 'close alignment' with single market (UK's choice) with 'shared institutions' (unlikely if not fully inside single market) and participation in various EU programmes (probably OK). Note: Labour will whip to support this amendment.

· (L) Revoke Article 50; Tabled by Joanna Cherry [SNP] - If the Gov’t has not passed a deal it would be required to stage a no-deal vote before 12th April scheduled departure, then in the scenario that MP’s do not authorise a no-deal PM May would be required to revoke Article 50. Fully within UK power as long as revocation is unconditional

· (M) Second ‘Confirmatory’ referendum; Tabled by Margaret Beckett [Lab] - Some Remainers have argued that the public now has a better understanding of Brexit and therefore should be asked again. Requires a long extension, which EU is likely to grant on these grounds. Note: Labour will whip to support this amendment.

· (O) Contingent Preferential Arrangements; Tabled by Marcus Fysh [Con] - Gov’t to attempt agree upon preferential trade agreements with the EU, in the scenario that a WA in not implemented. Not compatible with EU arrangements as some parts of “O” don’t exist in practice.

N.B. 2 - UK PM May’s deal does not feature amongst the amendments.

N.B. 3 - Labour Chief Whip has told backbenchers they will be whipped to support option M

N.B. 4 - Government will oppose business motion for indicative votes later, according to a PM May spokesman

N.B 5 - Conservative Whips have confirmed that tonight's indicative votes will be free votes with the cabinet abstaining from the vote, according to Conservative MP Cartlidge

N.B.6 - Due to the 29 cabinet & cabinet attenders abstaining from the vote, this reduces this total number of eligible MP's down to 609., Independent's Rentoul

content: A much narrower than expected US trade gap has taken a bit more of the shine off bonds coming hot on the heels of latest talk about the ECB implementing a tiered deposit system that already boosted bank stocks and risk sentiment overall. Bunds retreated a bit deeper below 166.00 before regrouping and Gilts went several steps further to post a new 129.07 Liffe low, while US Treasuries have whittled gains to single digits with the curve almost back to steady vs flatter or more pronounced inversion earlier. Elsewhere, the Usd is firmer on balance, and especially vs the Cad after a wider than forecast Canadian trade deficit, but the Gbp is bucking the general trend into tonight’s IVs.

(Newswires)

(Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 27th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities have been choppy [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.4%], following the significant downturn seen in risk sentiment after a somewhat mixed lead from Asia
  • House of Commons Speaker Bercow is to select indicative vote options around 15:00GMT/11:00EDT & voting is to begin around 19:30GMT/15:30EDT
  • Dollar has conceded some ground against G10 currencies, with the exception of antipodeans after the RBNZ providing a more dovish outlook on the rate path
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US and Canadian trade, DoEs, ECB’s, Mersch, de Galhua & Fed’s George

 

ASIA  

Asian equity markets were mixed as the region somewhat failed to maintain the broad positive momentum from US where all majors finished in the green with the gains led by outperformance in energy and financials. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) were both negative throughout the day although the Australian benchmark just about recovered at the close, while Tokyo stocks underperformed amid currency effects and mass ex-dividend day involving over 1000 stocks including blue-chips Mitsubishi UFJ, SoftBank and Sony. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) were initially indecisive amid continued PBoC liquidity inaction and as participants mulled over another deluge of earnings, as well as discouraging data in which February YTD Industrial Profits slumped by the most in nearly a decade. However, sentiment in China then improved with energy names boosted by the recent advances in oil, while there was also reports confirming that China and Italy signed an MOU to make Italy the first western European country to join the Belt & Road initiative. Finally, 10yr JGBs were slightly higher as they tracked the marginal gains seen in T-notes and as the subdued risk appetite in Japan kept prices afloat.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7141 (Prev. 6.7042)

Chinese Industrial Profits YTD (Feb) Y/Y -14.0% (Prev. -1.9%) widest decline since May 2009. (Newswires)

RBNZ kept their OCR on hold at 1.75% as expected and said more likely direction of next OCR move is down. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump's Fed board nominee Moore said the Fed should immediately cut rates by 50bps, while he added he is not a ‘sycophant’ for President Trump and is not dovish on monetary policy. (NYT)

UK/EU   

UK PM May will be urged by her own MPs to name the date of her departure today as the price of getting her Brexit deal through Parliament. (Telegraph) Note, PM May will be meeting with the 1922 Committee at 1700GMT today, according to Sky News. UK PM May's team are debating a potential timetable for her to stand down, which might not necessarily see her make the announcement before MV3, according to the FT. (FT)

UK Cabinet Minister now not expecting free votes for tonight's indicative votes as some demanded, risking further resignations; according to Sky News' Faisal Islam. BBC’s Nick Eardley added, however, that no decision has been made as of yet. (Newswires) Opposition Leader Corbyn is preparing to whip his MPs to back a move today that would keep Britain in the single market and customs union. (Times)

UK government rejected the petition to revoke Article 50 which was signed by 5.78mln people. (Newswires)

ECB’s Draghi says the ECB are now seeing a more persistent deterioration of external demand, adding that current data suggests that there are some signs that external demand may be effecting investment via manufacturing value chains within the Euro Area. (Newswires)

ECB's Praet says that In any case, we stand ready to adjust all of our instruments, as appropriate, to ensure sustained inflation convergence towards levels below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. (Newswires)

Bank of Italy's Visco says that they must guarantee financial stability with a clear strategy to lower public debt. (Newswires)

Italy's Confindustria hikes 2019 deficit forecast to 2.6% of GDP from 2.0% and see flat GDP growth of 0.9%. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

A relatively choppy session for European equities thus far [Eurostoxx 50 -0.4%] as sentiment soured after a mixed lead from Asia. Sectors are mostly lower although the consumer discretionary sector (+0.2%) is driving the gains amid the slew of positive news-flow for the auto sector. Renault (+3.4%) shares spiked higher at the open amidst fresh merger talks with Nissan ahead of a bid for Fiat Chrysler (+3.3%), whilst Daimler (+1.2%), BMW (+0.5%), and Volkswagen (+0.4%) shares also march in tandem. Reports stated Daimler was close to selling its 50% “Smart” stake to Geely, meanwhile Volkswagen struck a multi-year partnership with Amazon. Elsewhere utilities underperform despite its defensive properties with Centrica (-1.3%), National Grid (-1.4%), E.ON (-1.6%) all near the foot of their respective bourses. In terms of notable movers, Wirecard (-4.5%) shares shed some of yesterday’s gains after the company announced that some of its Singapore employees may face criminal liability regarding the ongoing accounting scandal. Finally, Swedbank (-7.8%) shares declined after the company confirmed that a search is currently underway at the head office, following on from reports that an internal investigation has been initiated by the Swedish Economic Crime Authority.

FX

NZD/AUD - The Antipodean Dollars are back on the rack, with the Kiwi sharply underperforming in wake of OCR cut revelations from the RBNZ overnight after an unexpected switch from neutral to easing mode amidst a bleaker assessment of the economy and heightened risks of a more pronounced downturn. Nzd/Usd slumped over a big figure in response and is clinging to 0.6800, as the Aud/Nzd cross extended recovery gains well beyond 1.0300 to circa 1.0450 before consolidating, and with Aud/Usd retreating to sub-0.7100 at one stage on the back of worrying Chinese data in the form of industrial profits (-14% y/y and weakest in almost 10 years).

NOK - Another G10 laggard following a rise in Norwegian unemployment vs the consensus for an unchanged jobless rate, with Eur/Nok back up above 9.6500 vs a more stable SEK around 10.4200 vs the single currency amidst mixed Swedish sentiment indicators, a wider trade surplus and 2019 GDP forecast upgrade via the NIER.

JPY/CHF/EUR - Relative outperformers and all firmer vs the Greenback as the Jpy benefits from renewed safe-haven positioning within a 110.70-30 range and moves further away from decent option expiry interest sitting between 110.70-75 (1.4 bn). Similarly, the Franc is benefiting from another downturn in risk sentiment and revisits recent highs around 0.9900 and through 1.1200 against the Euro, which looked vulnerable independently when testing Tuesday’s lows vs the Buck around 1.1250 before some timely support from ECB President Draghi who contended that a more sustained downturn in external demand and other factors have merely hampered rather than scuppered Eurozone inflation convergence towards target. Eur/Usd has subsequently rebounded relatively firmly to challenge Fib resistance at 1.1280, but could be capped ahead of 1.1300 given hefty expiries spanning 1.1255-65 (1.5 bn).

GBP/CAD - The Pound remains rangebound around 1.3200 vs the Usd awaiting the next chapter of Brexit and up to 16 amendments to be voted on in Parliament after the Letwin approval – see our headline feed for a situation update and detailed analysis of all the motions tabled that could be selected by the HoC Speaker later today. Note, Cable survived an early downside attempt, and like Eur/Usd held around yesterday’s base, but is likely to face some offers around 1.3250 by the same token. Elsewhere, the Loonie is losing some support from oil prices with Usd/Cad towards the top of a 1.3407-1.3376 band ahead of trade data from Canada and the US.

DXY - The index has come up against some psychological and chart resistance just shy of 97.000, with a Fib at 96.956 only marginally and briefly breached. Moreover, the broad Dollar has conceded ground to the aforementioned comeback in rival currencies.

FIXED INCOME

Some post-auction consolidation perhaps, but certainly no sign of any indigestion or reticence to snap up 10 year German debt and pay for the privilege. However, Bunds have drifted back down from their fresh/latest contract best (166.25) and the equivalent yield has nudged off circa -6 bp lows, with Gilts and US Treasuries largely following their lead, but the former bouncing again from a marginally lower Liffe low (129.38) and latter still well bid amidst further marked flattening. Back to Eurex, Italian BTPs bucking the bull trend on 2019 growth downgrades and fiscal implications that will lift the deficit further from 2%.

COMMODITIES

The oil complex is extending losses as the risk-off sentiment took the wheel. WTI (-0.8%) futures gave up the recently claimed USD 60/bbl and flirts closer to USD 59.50/bbl whilst Brent futures (-0.3%) rests just below USD 68.00/bbl. Last night’s APIs showed a surprise build of 1.9mln barrels (vs. Exp. draw of 1.2mln) with trader eyeing the release of this week’s DoEs as a fresh catalyst. Further supply side news-flow may also be contributing to the downside as sources stated that Russian oil output in March (so far) stood at 11.30mln BPD, only marginally lower from February’s 11.34mln BPD. Finally, oil officials noted that crude loading operations have resumed in Iraq’s Southern Terminals following a stoppage. Elsewhere metals are largely benefiting from the marginal pullback in the buck with gold (-0.2%) gains also exacerbated by safe-haven demand. However, dollar-induced upside in copper is capped by the risk averse sentiment as the red metal trades sideways. Finally, the majority of miners and port operators in Australia have resumed after 4-6 days of disruption following cyclone activity.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (22 March) +1.9mln vs. Exp. -1.2mln (prev. -2.133mln). (Newswires)

Saudi oil export value rose 0.5% Y/Y, according to reports. (Newswires)

The 10 year UK debt future is now consolidating off a 129.40 low in keeping with the Short Sterling strip that is nestling off best levels, but still firm overall (flat-1.5 ticks ahead vs +3 ticks at best in Dec20 and Mar21 contracts). Also ahead, CBI distributive trades are forecast to rise from a flat February, but not expected to prompt a great deal of reaction.

subject: Bunds: braced for clean 166.00 break and -5 bp 10 year yield
content: After Tuesday’s time out and a bout of tentative trade overnight, core bonds are back in bull-flattening mode with the 10 year German benchmark eking out a marginal new contract high at 166.06, while the corresponding cash rate has fallen to fresh multi-year lows just shy of -4 bp. Latest dovish impulses and positive momentum have been reignited to an extent by another global Central Bank shifting into easing mode (RBNZ), while Eurozone debt is also primed for a raft of ECB speakers that may reinforce recent the recent roll-back of rate guidance and introduction of TLTRO3. Technically, 166.12 forms the next line of resistance for Bunds ahead of 166.28 and then 166.48, while supply could also cause some congestion or indigestion with a Eur3 bn 2029 tap offered at a negative yield vs 0.25% coupon.

Wendel SA (MF FP) – Co. have entered into a EUR 200mln share repurchase agreement. (Newswires)

Swedbank (SWEDA SS) – An internal report shows that around EUR 135bln of money moved through a unit of the Co. which dealt with Russian clients in Estonia from 2008 to 2018. Report states that ‘major breaches’ of anti-money laundering obligations were highlighted. (SVT/FT)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – Co. have announced a strategic consultancy agreement with Movicel as part of their African partner markers programme. (Newswires)

Imperial Brands (IMB LN) – Co. are on track to meet net revenue and earnings expectations for the FY. Tobacco volume trends are slightly behind H2 2018. Co. says H1 EPS will be impacted by reduction of Logista stake and last year’s divestment of other tobacco products. (Newswires)

Bellway (BWY LN) – HY revenue GBP 1.488bln vs. Prev. GBP GBP 1.324bln. HY profit before tax GBP 319mln vs. Prev. GBP 288mln. Co. announce interim dividend of GBP 0.504 per share, +5.0%. Co. state that trading in the first half of the year has been positive, and they expect to achieve further growth through the rest of the year. (Newswires)

UK Companies – REC survey indicated that British companies have significantly reduced their investment and hiring plans due to Brexit. More Co’s were unoptimistic than optimistic regarding the outlook for jobs and investment for the first time since the survey began in June 2016. (Newswires)

Electrolux (ELUXB SS) – Co. reiterates its business outlook for FY 2019. (Newswires)

Telenor (TEL NO) – Co. sold a 5.7% of VEON for NOK 1.8bln. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

27th March 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mixed as the region somewhat failed to maintain the broad positive momentum from US where all majors finished in the green with the gains led by outperformance in energy and financials. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were both negative throughout the day although the Australian benchmark just about recovered at the close, while Tokyo stocks underperformed amid currency effects and mass ex-dividend day involving over 1000 stocks including blue-chips Mitsubishi UFJ, SoftBank and Sony. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were initially indecisive amid continued PBoC liquidity inaction and as participants mulled over another deluge of earnings, as well as discouraging data in which February YTD Industrial Profits slumped by the most in nearly a decade. However, sentiment in China then improved with energy names boosted by the recent advances in oil, while there was also reports confirming that China and Italy signed an MOU to make Italy the first western European country to join the Belt & Road initiative.

FTSE

Housing names – Housing Secretary has warned housebuilders that they must end punitive costs and snagging problems in new homes if they want to continue to benefit from the Help to Buy scheme. (Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

FERGUSON (FERG LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN CHASE

DAX

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Co. and Amazon (AMZN) have agreed on a strategic partnership to create an “industry cloud”; details will be announced soon. (Sueddeutsche)

BMW (BMW GY) – Co. will begin Chinese production of electric cars in 2021. (Nikkei)

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Soy producer associations in 10 Brazilian states have filed a legal petitions to get Co. to deposit royalties related to a soy seed technology into an escrow account, according to a document. Separately, FDA has approved orphan drug designation for their treatment of Haemophilia A. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY)/ Commerzbank (CBK GY) – German Finance Minister Scholz rejected accusations that he was pressuring the Co.’s to merge, and added that the government was in talks with the lenders so it could intervene if needed. Separately, Deutsche Bank has been warned by union bosses that they will prevent the integration of Postbank if a merger with Commerzbank (CBK GY) occurs, Co’s manager says he could not imagine a scenario in which unions would agree regarding the merger. (FT/Newswires)

Wirecard (WDI GY) – Co. announced that some of its Singapore employees may have to face criminal liability regarding the ongoing accounting scandals. (FT) For reference, the Co. yesterday stated that an investigation into their transactions found ‘no material impact’ on their financial reports.

CAC

Renault (RNO FP) – Co. intends to restart merger talks with Nissan (7201 JT) within 12-months, before setting its sight on a bid for Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM). Renault currently owns around 43% of Nissan. (FT/Newswires)

Carrefour (CA FP) – Co. is reportedly in talks with unions in France about 1500 job cuts, according to French Press. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Lufthansa (LHA GY) CEO said it plans to purchase a triple-digit number of either Boeing (BA) 737 Max or Airbus A320neo jetliners to replace its fleet. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Dassault System (DSY FP) – Co. proposes a dividend of EUR 0.65/shr. (Newswires)

Orpea (ORP FP) – FY Net EUR 220mln vs. Exp. EUR 222mln. EBITDA EUR 604mln vs. Exp. EUR 610mln. Pre-tax profit EUR 309mln vs. Prev. EUR 278mln. Revenue EUR 3.42bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.14bln. Within the next 12 months, Co. will sell between EUR 200-250mln of real estate. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Heineken (HEIA NA) – South Korea has begun a probe into the Co. and AE Brands Korea for allegedly manipulating prices in order to pay lower tariffs. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 27th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets were mixed as the region somewhat failed to maintain the broad positive momentum from US where all majors finished in the green
  • Opposition Leader Corbyn is preparing to whip his MPs to back a move today that would keep Britain in the single market and customs union
  • Note, House Speaker Bercow is set to name the options for indicative votes around 1500GMT today
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US and Canadian trade, DoEs, ECB’s Draghi, Praet, Lautenschlaeger, de Guindos, Mersch, de Galhua, Fed’s George

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed as the region somewhat failed to maintain the broad positive momentum from US where all majors finished in the green with the gains led by outperformance in energy and financials. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were both negative throughout the day although the Australian benchmark just about recovered at the close, while Tokyo stocks underperformed amid currency effects and mass ex-dividend day involving over 1000 stocks including blue-chips Mitsubishi UFJ, SoftBank and Sony. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were initially indecisive amid continued PBoC liquidity inaction and as participants mulled over another deluge of earnings, as well as discouraging data in which February YTD Industrial Profits slumped by the most in nearly a decade. However, sentiment in China then improved with energy names boosted by the recent advances in oil, while there was also reports confirming that China and Italy signed an MOU to make Italy the first western European country to join the Belt & Road initiative. Finally, 10yr JGBs were slightly higher as they tracked the marginal gains seen in T-notes and as the subdued risk appetite in Japan kept prices afloat.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7141 (Prev. 6.7042)

Chinese Industrial Profits YTD (Feb) Y/Y -14.0% (Prev. -1.9%) widest decline since May 2009. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK lawmaker Benn proposed a motion for today’s indicative votes that any Brexit deal must at least include a commitment to negotiate a permanent UK-wide customs union with the EU, whilst UK lawmaker Boles proposed a common market 2.0 motion for Wednesday's parliamentary vote. Furthermore, MPs also proposed a motion to compel the government to negotiate a new UK-EU customs union after the UK leaves the EU and also proposed an EEA-EFTA Norway option as well as a motion to revoke A50 if the UK does not get a deal. (Newswires) Note, House Speaker Bercow is set to name the options for indicative votes around 1500GMT today

 

UK PM May will be urged by her own MPs to name the date of her departure today as the price of getting her Brexit deal through Parliament. (Telegraph) Note, PM May will be meeting with the 1922 Committee at 1700GMT today, according to Sky News.

 

Opposition Leader Corbyn is preparing to whip his MPs to back a move today that would keep Britain in the single market and customs union. (Times)

 

UK government rejected the petition to revoke Article 50 which was signed by 5.78mln people. (Newswires)

Brexiteer lawmakers wrote in a letter to PM May that her move to delay Brexit raises "serious legal doubts" and asked the PM to fully explain the government's recent actions to delay Brexit. (Newswires)

 

Former UK Foreign Minister Johnson suggested that if we vote down UK PM May's Brexit deal again there is an appreciable and growing sense that we will not leave at all, although he added that he was 'not there yet' on backing the deal. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was firmer overnight and edged its way closer towards the 97.00 level as its major counterparts traded subdued in which EUR/USD extended on the recent data-driven weakness before it found support at 1.1250. GBP/USD was also softer overnight and slipped below the 1.3200 handle as it continued to range ahead of today’s indicative votes in Parliament where MPs are said to have tabled at least 16 proposals on alternative Brexit options. Elsewhere, the indecisive risk tone weighed on JPY-crosses but with the pressure on USD/JPY alleviated by a firmer greenback and support around 110.50 where several key DMA levels are closely located, while antipodeans underperformed with NZD/USD heavily weighed after the dovish surprise by the RBNZ which kept rates unchanged as expected but deviated from its past outlook for rates to move in either direction and now sees it more likely for the next OCR move to be a cut. This spurred an adjustment to forecasts in which ANZ Bank now sees a cut in November this year with the risk of a sooner reduction, while money markets were seen to price OCR cuts in November this year and in June next year. As such, NZD/USD fell below the 0.6900 handle and later breached 0.6800 to the downside, while AUD/USD suffered in sympathy to test support levels around 0.7100.

 

RBNZ kept the OCR on hold at 1.75% as expected and stated it is more likely the direction of next OCR move is down.

Furthermore, the RBNZ said the balance to inflation risk have shifted to the downside and global economic outlook has continued to weaken, although it added that low rates as well as increased government spending and investment is to support growth this year. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were relatively uneventful overnight amid the mixed risk sentiment which saw WTI crude futures remain near YTD highs around the 60.00/bbl level after oil prices were supported this week by supply-side factors. These include the temporary closure of the Houston ship channel and with operations at Venezuela’s main oil port Jose halted following a blackout. Furthermore, Russian Energy Minister Novak also affirmed they are in the process of achieving planned oil output cuts, while a surprise build in headline API crude inventories did little to dent oil’s recent performance which is on track for its best 3-month start to the year since 2002. Elsewhere, gold prices were constrained by strength in the greenback, while copper eked mild gains amid some resilience in risk appetite of its largest buyer China.

 

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (22 March) +1.9mln vs. Exp. -1.2mln (prev. -2.133mln). (Newswires)

Venezuela's crude upgraders are still not able to restart operations following the recent electricity blackout in the country, according to sources. (Newswires)

US

Soft European data helped put a floor beneath prices in early trade, though a constructive risk environment helped stocks move higher, seeing some selling. Real money reportedly scooped up intermediates, and range trading ensued as dealers sold into supply and there was some rate locking on investment grade issuance including an 8-tranche bond offering from Mars Inc, IGM said. Uninspiring US data helped contribute some positive ticks. The 2yr note auction was decent, stopping through the screens by 1.2bps; cover was above recent averages. The decent auction helped stabilise the TPLEX, but subdued trade resumed into the close. Once again, a lot of attention on the 3m/10yr curve, which remains inverted, though analysts have seemingly become more sanguine about the whole affair. US T-note futures settled 2+ ticks higher at 124-13.

Fed's Daly (non-voter, dove) said the Fed Funds Rate is now at neutral and reiterated patience as well as data-dependency, while she also commented the current appropriate policy is to be patient and the US economy is in a good place. (Newswires)

US President Trump's Fed board nominee Moore said the Fed should immediately cut rates by 50bps, while he added he is not a ‘sycophant’ for President Trump and is not dovish on monetary policy. (NYT)

US trade judge recommended an import ban on some Apple (AAPL) phones over a patent infringement of Qualcomm (QCOM), although Apple managed to avoid an import ban in a 2nd infringement case at the US International Trade Commission. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mixed with underperformance in Japan on mass ex-dividend day
content:
Asia equity markets are mixed as the region fails to maintain the positive momentum from US where all majors finished in the green with the broad sector gains led by outperformance in energy and financials. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) are negative with weakness seen in nearly all of Australia’s sectors aide from tech, while Tokyo stocks underperform amid currency effects and mass ex-dividend day involving over 1000 stocks including blue-chips Mitsubishi UFJ, SoftBank and Sony. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) are indecisive amid continued PBoC liquidity inaction and as participants mull over another deluge of earnings, while data was also discouraging in which February YTD Industrial Profits slumped by 14.3% Y/Y.

In FX markets, the DXY is firmer overnight and edges its way back up towards the 97.00 level as its major counterparts trade subdued, with EUR/USD extending on the recent data-driven weakness before finding some near-term support at 1.1250. GBP/USD is also softer overnight and has slipped below the 1.3200 handle with the pair ranging ahead of today’s indicative votes in Parliament where MPs are said to have tabled at least 16 proposals on alternative Brexit options. Elsewhere, the indecisive risk tone has weighed on JPY-crosses but with the pressure on USD/JPY alleviated by a firmer greenback and support around 110.50 where several key DMA levels are located, while antipodeans underperform with NZD/USD slumping after the dovish surprise by the RBNZ which kept rates unchanged as expected but deviated from its past outlook for rates to move in either direction and now sees it is more likely the direction of the next OCR move to be a cut.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are slightly higher with prices supported following the mild gains seen in T-notes and subdued risk appetite in Japan.
